nodes.text: Absolute income mobility in the United States has fallen substantially since 1940 and reviving high rates of absolute mobility would require economic growth that is distributed more broadly across the income distribution rather than merely higher aggregate GDP growth

Method: Estimate absolute mobility Ac for birth cohorts by decomposing the joint parent-child income distribution into children and parents marginal income distributions and the copula of parent and child income ranks and computing Ac = integral of indicator that child income quantile >= parent income quantile over the copula

Data: Children marginal distributions from CPS (March samples 1970-2014) for cohorts 1940-1984; parents marginal distributions from pooled decennial Census IPUMS samples (1940-2000); copula for 1980-1982 cohorts estimated nonparametrically from de-identified tax records linking >10 million parent-child pairs

Result (baseline): Under the copula-stability benchmark, fraction of children earning more than parents fell from about 92% for the 1940 birth cohort to about 50% for the 1984 cohort, with larger declines at middle and upper parent percentiles

Method / robustness for missing copula: For cohorts before 1980, assume copula stability as benchmark and compute nonparametric upper and lower bounds on absolute mobility for each cohort by linear programming over all copulas satisfying first-order stochastic dominance and row/column integration constraints

Evidence (bounds): Bounds on absolute mobility are tight for early cohorts (e.g., 1940 cohort bounded 84% to 98%) and wide for recent cohorts, implying that missing historical panel data do not prevent reliable characterization of the declining trend

Claim: The widening of bounds for recent cohorts arises because income growth between parents and children overlapped much more for recent cohorts than for early cohorts, making mobility sensitive to the copula when distributions overlap

Sensitivity checks: Decline in absolute mobility is robust to alternative price deflators (PCEPI, PPI, CPI adjustments), measuring income after taxes and transfers, measuring income at age 40, family-size adjustments, individual versus family income, and accounting for plausible underreporting; qualitative decline persists

Heterogeneity: Declines in absolute mobility occurred across all states and both genders for family-income comparisons, with especially large declines in the industrial Midwest and a pronounced decline in sons earning more than fathers when measured at the individual level

Counterfactual simulations: Two scenarios for 1980 cohort â€” (A) higher GDP growth (raise GDP per working-age family to midcentury growth rates but allocate 2010 GDP across households as in 2010) raises absolute mobility to 62% (partial recovery), (B) more broadly shared growth (allocate 2010 GDP across households as in 1940 cohort) raises absolute mobility to 80%, reversing >70% of the decline

Claim: Increasing aggregate GDP growth alone, given the current unequal distribution of growth, has modest effects on average absolute mobility and would require unrealistically high sustained growth rates (>5% per working-age family) to restore midcentury mobility levels
Claim: Reallocating existing GDP growth so that growth is shared broadly across the income distribution can restore much of the decline in absolute mobility even without higher aggregate growth
Conclusion 1: Absolute income mobility has fallen markedly since 1940, from roughly 90% to around 50%, with the largest declines in the middle and upper parts of the parental income distribution

Conclusion 2: The decline in absolute mobility is driven more by the unequal distribution of economic growth (who receives gains) than by the slowdown in aggregate GDP growth alone; high absolute mobility requires broad-based growth across the income distribution

Limitation: Copula for pre-1970 cohorts is unobserved and results rely on the copula-stability benchmark and bounding approach; bounds widen for recent cohorts where copula is not known but are tight in early cohorts enabling confident inference about long-run decline
